Is there a similar resource provided by the FCC for individuals studying for the technician license?</s> 
Yes, there is currently a similar resource provided by the FCC for individuals studying for the technician license. The FCC has an official website that provides free study materials, including a new online license course and practice test questions for all three license levels. You can find the website at https://www.fcc.gov/forms/eplan. The website requires you to register with your name and email address, but otherwise provides a comprehensive source for license study materials.

However, below is some general information regarding amateur radio bands and FCC regulations in the USA that might help answer this question:

- Depending on the frequency range, the FCC regulates amateur radio activities in the USA in different bands and channels. Each of these bands has different power and licensing requirements.
- The 630 meter band or 472-479 kHz is an amateur radio band that is largely used for communication with other amateur operators, as well as for experimentation with long-distance VLF (Very Low Frequency) propagation modes.
- Under Part 97 of the FCC Rules and Regulations, amateur radio operators are required to receive a license from the FCC before transmitting on certain frequencies.
- In the USA, the power limitations for amateur radio operators are typically categorized as High, Middle, Low, and Novice. Additionally, the FCC requires amateur radio operators to operate their transmitters so that the field strength of their signals does not exceed certain thresholds.
- Overall, it is recommended to seek guidance from the FCC or your local amateur radio clubs and experienced operators to fully understand the regulations and how to apply them in your specific case.
